BC-SCI-ANIMALS-COMPUTERS-NYT 
WHAT DO BLUE JAYS LIKE TO EAT? ASK A VIRTUAL MOTH 

  
 (Attn: Neb., Mich.)  (The Science Times) 
 (af)  
 By CAROL KAESUK YOON   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   The scene has been played out again and again over the
millennia: A hungry bird spies a bug and pounces, driving its beak
into its hearty insect meal. Now, in a twist on this ancient story,
scientists are training birds to aim at virtual insects,
computer-generated fakes at the heart of a growing field of
ecology.

   An increasing number of such bloodless creatures are being
shaped, colored and directed on the computer screen as researchers
find new ways to explore a wide array of questions about why real
animals act the way they do. The virtual menagerie already in use
by biologists includes spiders, flies, chickens and fish, variously
posed as prey, predators or alluring mates.

   ``What we have here is a virtual ecology,'' said Dr. Alan B.
Bond, who along with Dr. Alan C. Kamil, a fellow behavioral
ecologist at the University of Nebraska, carried out a study
reported in the current issue of the journal Nature. ``The blending
of the living animal and the computer model allows us to ask
questions that were inaccessible.''

   Bond and Kamil were interested in the longstanding question of
why members of a single species may have very different color
patterns. One popular hypothesis was that the variation results
when predators focus on hunting down the most common type until it
becomes rare and then switch to hunt whatever has become the common
type in its place. By doing so, they would prevent any one color
type from being hunted into oblivion.

   But the hypothesis has been difficult to test. Field studies
involved things like leaving out banquets of differently colored
worms fashioned of pastry and coming back to see what the birds had
taken. But while researchers saw that the common type was favored,
they were unable to show that birds actively switched their
favorite from one type to another as frequencies of different types
changed.

   On the computer, however, researchers created a virtual
population of differently patterned black-and-white winged moths,
based on the wing pattern of actual underwing moths. The computer
then drew sample moths from the virtual population and offered them
to the birds. Pecked moths were considered killed and were removed
from the population.

   Researchers saw that the birds tended to attack the common types
and pass on the uncommon types, just as predicted, as different
types waxed and waned in frequency.

   It took researchers two months to train each blue jay to
recognize on-screen moths as food items, but once they did,
researchers say the birds went at the images with such vigor that
they had to place a protective shield over the screen to keep the
jays from shattering the monitors.

   Although the blue jays were slow to catch on, some animals
respond instantly to a computer-generated meal.

   When shown a computer-generated insect, toads ``will look at it,
hop over to it and actually put their tongue on the screen trying
to get it,'' said Dr. David Clark, an animal behaviorist at Alma
College in Michigan who is also doing virtual experimentation. A
praying mantis, he said, will stalk a virtual fly and lunge its
legs at it.

   Clark has also worked with spiders and finds that females do
their come-hither leg tapping at the sight of virtual males
performing just the right courtship behaviors. He said he had been
able to tease apart the important elements of courtship by creating
male spiders of varying color patterns (something he said would
have killed real animals if done with paint) and programming them
to perform combinations of behaviors that no actual spider would
ever do.

   But not all animals take to computers so readily.

   ``I tried showing snakes mice walking around on a little
screen,'' Clark said. ``I didn't have much luck.'' Lizards were
similarly unimpressed.

   Part of the problem, researchers said, is that computer monitors
are specifically built to reproduce the world for the human eye.

   Bird color vision, for example, ``is so very different and so
much better than ours,'' said Dr. John A. Endler, an evolutionary
biologist at James Cook University in Australia, that using color
images may always be an impossibility with them. (Researchers on
the new study used black and white patterned moths.)

   Exploring the technology and discovering what animals find
convincing is all part of this new field, just as it was years ago
when biologists began playing taped recordings of frog, bird and
insect songs _ now a tried and trusted experimental technique _ to
see if animals would respond.

   Bond and Kamil are also using birds known as Clark's nutcrackers
to study the three-dimensional problem of spatial memory _ that is,
how a bird remembers where it stored all its bits of food _ a
seemingly perfect experimental problem to solve using virtual
reality. But even if the birds are ready, the researchers may not
be.

   After spending two months training blue jays to peck a computer
screen, Bond realizes it would take a tremendous amount of work to
train Clark's nutcrackers to react naturally to a
computer-generated three-dimensional space.

   ``I just wouldn't want to think of what you'd have to do to get
reliable virtual reality with a nutcracker,'' Bond said.
